pros: Small campus, friendly, student-centered community

pros: Generally the staff and faculty are committed to Providing the students here are the quality education, increasing access, and approach every day in service to the college.
cons: Deficits balloon, spending is cut on student services, critical staffing, and Deans/Directors are treated with a revolting lack of respect. Content experts with years of experience are dismissed out of hand, not invited to meetings that involve critical decisions about their areas responsibility, and have budgets they are not allowed to develop, manage or challenge. The priorities of this institution are so skewed towards athletics, haphazard and failing approaches to enrollment, and for years Deficits balloon, spending is it on student services, critical staffing, and dept. Deans and Directors are treated with a revolting lack of respect. Content experts with years of experience I just missed out of hand, not invited to meetings that involve critical decisions about their area responsibility, and are handed budgets that they are not allowed to manage or challenge. The priorities of this institution are so skewed towards athletics, haphazard approaches to enrollment, and an absolute paralysis in critical decision-making, leadership and financial management at the top.

pros: Overall a nice place to work. Students were respectful, and the average student had a good work ethic. I liked the smaller environment where everyone in my department (students and faculty) knew each other and were friendly.
cons: Some things were a little disorganized. After my first year, new contracts were never made even though I was working as adjunct on a yearly basis. To me, they were excessive with their COVID protocol, although all protocol is now lifted since March 2022. Pay for adjuncts is not the worst in the area but not great.

review_title: I genuinely enjoyed working here until I knew better.
job_title: Network Security Administrator in Albion, MI
pros: Excellent work-life balance.  Plenty of unofficial "perks" depending on what department you work in.  Overall sense of providing a service to advance higher education.  Good place to learn a career path.
cons: Location.  It's a minimum of 20-30 minute commute depending on how close you choose to live.  If you live in the small town, there are almost no amenities.   Can't keep talent due to pay that is "good for the area", but not enough when you commute from somewhere with higher property values.  Limited career advancement opportunities.  Place has been in constant management turmoil since the last recession.  Due to that, the financial situation stayed rather grim.  There were no raises for years.

review_title: Working as a student employee at the college
pros:
I had a great position as a student employee at the college library. These pros are for the library position only. The pros are:
- Good people as coworkers/supervisors
- Healthy work-life/study balance
- Simple job duties
- Easy way to make money while being a student full-time
cons:
The cons are for the student employee position at the library are:
- Occasional oversight by supervisors
- Lack of training beyond the bare minimum
- Supervisors occasionally held grudges

review_title: A great place to make some extra money while being a student
pros:
- Very accommodating to your schedule
- Loved everyone I worked with
- They care about your well-being
- I've gotten lots of free food
cons: They're making me fill out cons, but there really isn't anything negative I have to say about the experience. If there were any problems, I would have already willfully addressed them with management.

review_title: Great Place To Work If You Have A Family
pros:
Very Flexible
Lots of time off if you include holidays
Working from home occasionally can be an option
cons:
Advancement is rare, and there's no ranking (for example, no "senior" positions to get promoted to)
Compensation is low even for the sector

pros: Fun atmosphere.  They'd bring in snacks for staff and the company Benson-Technology that they brought in that ran everything smoothly.
cons: They had you call alumni who graduated the previous year (most likely people who weren't in a position to donate) as well as parents of currently enrolled students.
